content: The Relative Strength (RS) Rating for Mettler Toledo International (MTD) jumped into a new percentile Thursday, as it got a lift from 68 to 71. The grade shows how a stock's price performance over the trailing 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. History reveals that the best stocks tend to have an RS Rating of over 80 in the early stages of their moves. See if Mettler Toledo International can continue to rebound and clear that threshold. Indexes pared gains in afternoon trading Wednesday. The Nasdaq continued to lead as components Facebook (FB) and Netflix (NFLX) traded in unusually heavy volume.The Nasdaq composite was up 0.5% but had been up as much as 0.8%. Facebook, the fifth-largest component of the Nasdaq, rose 1.3%. Volume was running above average, enough to put Facebook on IBD's Stocks On The Move list. The company is expected to benefit from a Hollywood writers' strike. Netflix, another big Nasdaq component, fell 1.8% in about double its usual volume. The video streaming company is breaking support at the 50-day moving average, putting the stock in a perilous spot.The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.3% — a loss almost entirely at the hands of IBM (IBM). Big Blue gapped down 5% in huge volume after its Q1 sales missed expectations, and analysts responded by cutting price targets on the stock.The S&P 500 had only a small part of its early gain left, up 0.1%. The index met resistance at the 50-day moving average. It's the second time this week that's happened, and it should give investors pause.Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE. Winning stocks beat losers by 9-to-7 on the NYSE and by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Auto dealers, medical equipment, department stores, chip equipment and airlines were the top industry groups. Earnings caused some of those moves. For example, Lam Research (LRCX) stock gapped up to a record high after the company beat profit estimates and raised its forecast.Education stocks DeVry Education Group (DV) and New Oriental Education (EDU) gained. DeVry climbed back above a 34.58 buy point in mediocre volume. China-based New Oriental surged 4% to a new high. It is extended from a 52.47 buy point. The company announces earnings Monday.Rev Group (REVG) soared 3%, though in lighter-than-normal volume. The maker of RVs, fire trucks, buses and other specialized vehicles broke out past the 28.15 buy point of a choppy cup-with-handle base. It's the first base for the stock, which had its IPO in January.Mettler Toledo (MTD) broke out past the 490.02 buy point of a flat base. The move came just as the precision instrument maker's shares found support at the 50-day moving average, a favorable aspect.Wix.com (WIX), which broke out less than three weeks ago, has already flashed a sell signal. The stock erased all of an 11% gain from its 71.20 buy point. Shares of the provider of websites and related tools pared losses as they tumbled almost to the 50-day moving average.RELATED:IBM Sinks Following 'Lackluster Performance' With Q1 Results, Analyst CutsLam Research, Gear Makers Jump On Upbeat March Quarter Reports

Good earnings reports continued to fuel breakouts Friday. MSCI (MSCI) broke out of a saucer-type base after reporting earnings that topped expectations on Thursday. The operator of hundreds of stock indexes reported a 23% rise in adjusted earnings per share. Operating revenue climbed 7% to $292.8 million. Shares rose 2.74 to 91.65, closing in buy range from the 90.89 buy…

The stock indexes pared gains in Friday's final minutes, but closed the session higher and erased most of their losses from Thursday's drubbing.The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, fading in the final minutes to close just below the 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq also rose 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 advanced 1.1%. The Dow utilities average, however, slid 0.8%.Volume was tracking lower across the board. Friday is the final day of the third quarter, and that can result in some volatility as fund managers make last-minute "window dressing" moves to make their portfolios look as good as possible.Retail stocks were among the strongest in Friday's trading. The sector's rise got started with Costco's (COST) 3.4% burst on better-than-expected earnings. Same-store sales rose 3%, excluding fuel and currency factors. The stock bounced after falling for seven weeks.IBD's Retail-Major Discount Chains industry group also got a boost from Wal-Mart (WMT), which climbed 2% after KeyBanc late Thursday initiated coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 90 price target. Costco and Wal-Mart are basing but remain below their 50-day moving averages.In online retail, Amazon.com (AMZN) made a new high and was among the stocks drawing the most volume on a relative basis. The stock is extended after finding support at its 50-day moving average a couple of weeks ago. Amazon was already a big winner from a breakout in April, when it made its second touch of the 50-day line. Yet, it has continued to march higher from that follow-on entry.Financials bounced back on a report that Deutsche Bank (DB) was close to settling a mortgage-securities case with U.S. regulators for $5.4 billion, far less than the $14 billion that the Justice Department sought. Deutsche shares jumped 14%. The SPDR Financial (XLF) exchange traded fund was up 1.4% after sinking 1.4% on Thursday.Mettler-Toledo International (MTD) broke out of a flat base, rising 3% and clearing the 416.85 buy point.  But volume was light. The company, which was added to the S&P 500 index about a month ago, makes precision measuring equipment and is the largest supplier of inspection systems for food, medicine and other industries.RELATED:Facebook's Zuckerberg, Nvidia, Qualcomm, EA, Top Insider TradesDeutsche Bank Jumps On Report $5.4 Billion Settlement NearAre Markets Voting For Clinton — Or For Divided Government?

Technology and banking stocks accounted for a big chunk of the new highs Friday. But the only breakout came from the electronic instruments field.Mettler-Toledo International (MTD) edged past the 416.85 buy point of a flat base. Shares rose 12.50 to 419.83, but volume was modestly above average. Mettler-Toledo has a good EPS Rating, although EPS gains ranged from 9% to 15% the past 14 quarters. Sales performance has been even milder, from declines of 4% to gains of 6%.The company, which was added to S&P 500 index about a month ago, makes precision measuring equipment and is the largest supplier of inspection systems for food, medicine and other industries.Strength in chips continued with talk of a possible NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) acquisition by Qualcomm (QCOM). NXP rose 5.89 to 102.01; Qualcomm added 1.05 to 68.50.Xilinx (XLNX) made a new high after finding support at the 50-day moving average. Shares rose 0.85 to 54.34 as the chip designer got swept up in merger talk itself. One analyst said the company might make a good takeover by Broadcom (AVGO).Logitech (LOGI) is trying to break out past the 22.52 buy point of a flat base. Shares of the computer peripherals maker closed at 22.46, up 0.11. The chart displays some high quality, with tight price action the past six weeks and support as shares came down to the 10-week moving average. High volume in the week of Sept. 23, when shares closed 2.7% higher, indicates institutional buying.RELATED:Analysts Bullish On Possible Qualcomm-NXP Merger

Money manager Vladimir “Val” de Vassal holds the same kind of leading stocks that you probably try to buy. But can you say your portfolio has outperformed 98% of your peers?De Vassal of Glenmede Investment Management aims to remove messy emotion from his buy and sell decisions. That adds to his performance in the long run, he says.Through May 31, he and his colleagues, including co-manager Paul Sullivan, have steered $2.3 billion Glenmede Large Cap Growth Fund (GTLLX) to average annual gains that topped all but 2% of their large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. over the past three and five years.Since de Vassal took the reins in early 2004, the mutual fund has scored a 9.16% average annual gain, while the S&P 500 averaged 7.26%.The fund’s star performance over both the long and short term make it an IBD Best Mutual Funds 2016 Awards winner, shining in three categories — U.S. equity funds, growth funds and large caps.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month LeadersIn an interview with IBD from his Philadelphia office, De Vassal, 56, shared some of his investing secrets. Here’s what he had to say about the techniques that allow his investing team to beat the S&P time and again:IBD: You have a quantitative investment approach. What does that mean, and how do you mix in fundamental research with that?De Vassal: I look at our process as a quantitative discipline based on fundamental insights. I worked with fundamental managers for 20 years. They were value-oriented, growth-oriented, small-cap, large-cap, even international. Basically, one of my responsibilities was objectively assessing their criteria in selecting stocks in their particular sectors or universe, and assessing what worked and what didn't.And I've tried to remove the emotion and subjectivity out of the process.So we've built a library of the factors that worked and that didn't. They're different for different sectors. If you talk with a tech analyst versus a utility analyst, they talk about very different metrics as to why a company is effective or not.So we've built models that are unique for each sector. Some factors may be similar, but when we look at stocks, we look at them relative to their peers in the sector in terms of their attractiveness. This is a continual process every year.We add each year of data to our analysis. And we'll test new ideas.We have dialogue with our internal portfolio managers and analysts. We also have dialogue with some leading Street research firms like Empirical (Research Partners), Bernstein, JPMorgan (JPM) and Citi (C).IBD: What type of market does your approach work best in?De Vassal: Our process works when valuations and earnings matter. We look to create a portfolio that is cheap with high cash flow versus its benchmark, but has strong consistent profitability. And the stocks we own are likely to have positive earnings and revenue surprises, and fewer negative earnings and revenue surprises, than the benchmark.Where the strategy can struggle is when investors are distracted by macro issues. In the financial crisis in the Great Recession, earnings didn't matter. Investors fled equities, and they didn't care at what price.In that situation, when investors are not focused on specific company fundamentals but are driven by macro and behavioral issues, our models have less efficacy.IBD: What about more recently?De Vassal: Other periods when the strategy underperforms would be risk rallies, like 2009, and we've had a pretty strong risk rally starting in March this year, when a lot of the riskiest names are outperforming, in the last couple of months.But in this risk rally, there's been a lot of price dislocation when you look across stocks within sectors, a lot of gap between high- and low-priced stocks measured on, say, price-to-book.So this year's risk rally is a good environment for active equity managers because there seems to be a large arbitrage opportunity between cheap and expensive stocks that maybe can be taken advantage of. Those create opportunities for future price appreciation.IBD: So you like the current market?De Vassal: Our indicators still suggest we're in a positive growth environment for the U.S. economy. We had two weak quarters in Q4 and Q1. But our models suggest we should expect a rebound. Most economists expect 2% to 3% annualized growth in GDP for this quarter and the next couple of quarters.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category PerformanceWe favor more cyclical sectors right now, like technology and consumer discretionary. We're underweight in interest-rate sensitive sectors like utilities and REITs.IBD: Let's talk about how you put your strategy to work. How does Edwards Lifesciences (EW) fit in? All of my questions are as of your latest disclosure.De Vassal: We owned it as of Jan. 31. It had good return on equity, over 20%. More sell-side analysts were raising than lowering estimates for the year and next year. The valuation was not cheap. But the fact that more analysts are raising estimates and that it has strong profitability and momentum -- historically, strong earnings growth offsets a rich valuation. And that's why we included this stock.IBD: What other holdings were you attracted to for similar reasons?De Vassal: Other names we bought in January were Oracle (ORCL), Masco (MAS), Schwab (SCHW). Again, they were attractive based on our criteria, a combination of earnings growth and analysts' estimates.One stock we sold in January was H&R Block (HRB). It was in the bottom quintile of its sector. Fortunately -- it's down 40% since we sold it.If there's something hitting one of our downside screens, we force it out of the portfolio. No questions asked.It takes time for fundamental analysts and portfolio managers to fall in love with a stock. But once they put it into a portfolio, it's hard for them to let go. We try to remove that emotion out of the process. In the long term, that adds to our performance.IBD: How does your approach differ from a fundamentals-only fund manager's?De Vassal: We look for stock that is cheap and has positive growth metrics and (whose coverage) analysts are raising estimates. We just look at what criteria work best in differentiating stocks in a sector. If it's a health care company, we don't look at what's in their pipeline, for example. Our stock ranking model for health care emphasizes high free cash flow yield, low relative price-to-book, strong reinvestment rate and positive earnings and revenue estimate revisions.IBD: Facebook (FB) has three quarters of accelerating earnings-per-share growth. How do you look at this holding?De Vassal: It's attractive in our models. Its valuation is not cheap. But its fundamentals and growth story are positive. So is the fact that analysts are raising estimates.There have been periods when we sold Facebook because it was getting too rich. Last year, the FANG stocks (Facebook, Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google, which is now Alphabet (GOOGL)) were just flying. But their valuations got too rich, and we wouldn't hold on. But at this point, Facebook would still be considered a buy in our models.IBD: You opened a stake in Lowe's (LOW) just last year. What was your thesis?

De Vassal: We started our stake in June 2015. It ranked in the top third of our stock-ranking models. It had positive (revenue and earnings) estimate revisions from sell-side analysts. Valuation was not too extreme. The price-earnings ratio on this year's earnings was under 20.Our stock-ranking models are based on 12-month periods. We look to turn over about 1/12th of the portfolio each month to maintain attractiveness. Every month we look to refresh and harvest losses to offset short-term gains in particular.IBD: Cadence Design's (CDNS) earnings-per-share growth has accelerated for two quarters. What's your quant view?De Vassal: It has had very positive earnings revisions. When we ran this in January, every analyst raised estimates for this company. Its P-E is not that expensive. It was 17.7 in January. It has done well and is now a little over 20.IBD: Thinly traded Mettler Toledo (MTD) is in an uptrend, but its EPS growth is slowing slightly. What's your view?De Vassal: It is still attractively ranked in our model. Estimate revisions are more neutral. But we showed positive for looking forward on analysts' estimates. It has very strong profitability, very high ROE. January ROE was over 40%. Some was contingent on book value. It's decelerating, but historically their growth has been over 10%. Looking forward, this still looks like double-digit growth, even if low double digits.IBD: You've been boosting your stake in Accenture (ACN). Why?De Vassal: It has a very attractive rank in the tech sector for us. Analysts at the margins are raising their estimates. It has high ROE and a good track record of dividend growth.IBD: What makes you different from other quant-oriented fund managers?De Vassal: The difference is in four principles.First, we believe in active management, and that stocks get mispriced. One issue with benchmark indices is that if a stock is overpriced, effectively it is overweighted. To address that, we ignore weights of individual stocks. We want to avoid the idiosyncratic risk of overexposure to a single name. If everything else is equal between a midcap and a mega-cap name, why wouldn't you invest in both instead of overweighting one just because it has a larger weight in the benchmark?Second, we treat each sector differently. I don't believe one model should be used for all stocks. Stocks in different sectors have different attributes and business models.Third, downside risk screens, including quality of earnings; avoiding companies with poor stock quality, debt and/or high idiosyncratic risk.Fourth, we differentiate stocks that are more likely to have positive versus negative surprises based on sell-side analyst behavior, company fundamentals and technical data.IBD: The idea behind your quantitative approach is that it homes in on the factors that identify stocks which outperform and it enables you to avoid being sidetracked by subjective factors that are, basically, irrelevant to outperformance, right?De Vassal: Yes, we build extensive back tests going back 20 years-plus, that identify which combinations of criteria would create a portfolio of stocks that outperform the average stock in the sector on a rolling 12-month basis, and which would be in the top 20%, the most attractive stocks.IBD: What about risk?De Vassal: We're looking for the most consistent excess return over rolling 12-month periods. So we're looking for the highest return per unit of shortfall risk. And shortfall risk would be any (stock) that didn't outperform the average stock by at least 200 basis points.We want to have upside, but we don't want to have much downside performance relative to the average stock.IBD: Some managers portray themselves as people who eat and sleep fund management, doing nothing else. But you've got at least one interesting hobby. Tell me about it, please.De Vassal: Well, one of my hobbies is genealogy. My last name is French. It's an old French name. We have a family tree going back more than 1,000 years. Apparently family members did a thousand-year reunion in 1987. We learned about it after the fact.We have a lot of documentation, interesting history. Our family went from France to the Ukraine in the early 1800s. We actually, this past Saturday, we saw relatives that we didn't know about. One, she was my third cousin. We got in touch through a Frenchman who was doing genealogical research on my family, and we ended up connecting for the first time.

Global mkts continue to come under pressure; Chinese stocks fall, Emerging mkts decline, Japanese stocks hemorrhage  as the commodity rout continues, Mining stocks suffer, oil continues to get hammered, global growth concerns send European mkts into a tailspin......Transportation stocks get clobbered and here at home the US mkts convulse as the focus returns to the 'lack of growth, concerns over the weakening Chinese economy (disappointing trade data), a collapsing oil mkt, a stronger dollar ,  weakening US macro data .......all amid a possible  'rising rate environment'....... The broad sell-off that has shown its ugly face over the past week has affected  all global markets....and often sell-offs like this end up being great buying opportunities....and this one will too.....leaving many to ask - But when?  The technical underpinnings of the mkt continue to weaken and break down - mkt breadth gets a bit weaker with each session........ December which started off  a bit  overbought....is less so now.....(mtd -3.6%)   but from a more intermediate-term perspective, the mkt still appears to be unsettled and may encounter some rough spots in the weeks ahead.. For the past month we have seen the Dow transports get clobbered - now down 10% since late November and down a whopping 18+% ytd.......What does this really say? Why has the FED chosen to ignore these very real warning signs?    Are we headed for a recession? Are we already in a recession?  Look, In a recession, demand dries up - then businesses pull back, and then shipping and transportation names suffer........but you say - Yes, but gas is cheap! Oil is down 41% ytd - gasoline is averaging $2.69/gal..... OK....but if demand dries up and companies can't sell products it's NOT about the gas!   Stocks closed lower again yesterday in what was another choppy session, oil continued to fall, global mkts continued to get hammered, commodities gasping for breath,  the S&P fighting to find support.....testing and breaking key technical support levels....2065 then 2045...only to find temporary support at 100 dma of 2032......If this support gets broken again - you could see the bottom fall out...-  and test the likes of 1950/1975 ish.....

Look the mkt is tired, its frustrated with lack of leadership, It is not sure it really believes any of the rhetoric coming out of the FED.  Earnings for the 4Q are expected to decline by 4.5% while 2016 projections are coming under renewed scrutiny.  Margin pressure is seen rising,  sentiment gauges flashing 'caution ahead'...and never mind the divergence in Dow theory with the Transports down 18+% ytd while the Dow Industrials are only off by 1.8% ytd.Taken together - these factors present a picture of anxiety for investors, causing some to pull back and wait until they see how the mkt really reacts to next weeks' expected rate rise and future guidance.  Technically mkt breadth  continues to deteriorate.....New lows outpacing new highs.. on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE.......and what this says is that while the indices appear to be closer to the highs - the internals of the broader mkt are under pressure......spelling potential trouble ahead... The Russell Small Cap Index (RTY)  has been unable to recover - having broken all 3 key technical supports and is now challenging the November lows - right here at 1145 -  and now looking at a 'black hole' which could cause it to revisit the October lows of 1085...or a 5% move lower from here....which would represent an 11% ytd decline - if that happens.  So look - it ain't pretty right now....which makes us wonder what data sets is the FED using to gauge real economic activity and sentiment?   Job Growth?  Really?  As the threat of a recession looms large, we will see the 'flight to safety' trade....the large cap, solid dividend paying listed companies  will be the 'safe haven' (or safer haven)  trade as a defensive maneuver by large institutions to weather the storm of the approaching hurricane...

After falling nearly every day in December,  the mkt is now oversold and that would suggest a bounce ahead as the mkt tries to find its footing.  And this morning US Futures are fighting to move higher.....At 5 am they were ahead by  10 pts and now at 7 am they are only up 6 pts......as they battle to stay in positive territory......Keep your eyes on 2032......a breach here will ignite the algos - sell side orders will hit the mkt while the buyers retreat......I mean - why would you  stand in front of a moving train?  (Barring the obvious answer!) Overnight global mkts continue to fall....in Asia - Japan is at a 1 month low falling 1.32%, Hong Kong lost 0.45%, China -0.50% and ASX -0.84%.    In Europe - mkts continue to bleed as the rout in oil and other commodities as well as weakness in Asia rip the wound wide open......never allowing it to scab over..... Economically, there was more bad inflation data from Europe.  French CPI was flat yoy vs. (E) 0.2%, further justifying the ECB’s QE expansion last week while providing a reason for even more...FED policy, a stronger dollar and broader macro concerns continue to be the story.   FTSE -0.47%, CAC 40 0.145%, DAX  -0.16%, Eurostoxx -0.32%, Spain  -0.08% and Italy  -0.07%.

There are no mkt moving eco stats today at all.....so expect the focus to be on the Oil story and the FED story.....If the bottom falls out before next Tuesday - Will that cause the FED to 're-think' it's  'strong economy' story????  I'm just sayin'.....Take good care - Kp

Precision-instrument maker Mettler-Toledo International (MTD) got a bullish response from Wall Street after it beat Q4 expectations late Wednesday, sending shares up more than 5% on the stock market today.Mettler-Toledo's Q4 profit rose 10% over the year-earlier quarter to $3.82 a share, beating analysts' consensus by 8 cents. Revenue rose 4% to $684.3 million, more than $10 million better than estimates. The company added a nickel to its 2014 EPS guidance, now $11.40 to $11.60 vs. $10.58 last year. Revenue was guided to grow 3% to 4% this year."The clear highlight was growth outperformance in Europe (boosted by easy comps)," wrote analyst Ross Muken of ISI Group in a note late Wednesday. "From a segment perspective, better-than-expected Lab results (strength in Asia and EU) and a return to growth in Industrials ... counteracted revenue declines in Food Retailing."Muken added a buck to his price target, now 253, and maintained his neutral rating. UBS analyst Daniel Arias upgraded the stock to buy from neutral, lifting his price target to 263 from 245. In midday trading Thursday, shares were around 248.Mettler-Toledo's report continued a pretty good earnings season for the Electronics-Scientific/Measuring group. Danaher (DHR) and Waters (WAT) both gained after beating Q4 estimates, though the stocks have since retreated in the larger market selloff. Agilent (A) is due to report next Thursday and Bruker (BRKR) the following Tuesday.Follow Amy Reeves on Twitter: @IBD_Areeves.
Lately, the Electronics-Scientific Measuring industry group has been as reliable as a fine Swiss watch.
Week in, week out it has been among the top 20 in IBD's 197 industry groups, based on six-month price performance.
It's No. 20 this week, up from 75 seven months ago.
Most of the group's surge relative to the S&P 500 has come since the market trough in late August.
The group has benefited from several macro trends. Those range from the explosion in bandwidth capacity to the graying of America and the rest of the world.
"The group's products and services are diverse," said Dana Cease, analyst for John Hancock Asset Management. "Its companies benefit from a wide range of macro forces."
The group has two subsets: life sciences and diagnostics in one camp, and electronics in the other.
Life sciences tends to have steadier revenue and earnings than the electronics subset.
"Their customers are more price-elastic," Cease said. "They are hospitals, R&D centers and universities, which often pay whatever its new equipment costs."
M&A activity in late 2010 spotlighted two deals that featured high premiums. Danaher's (DHR) takeover bid pushed Beckman Coulter (BEC) to 72 from 57. Now it's settled in at 83.
Thermo Fisher Scientific's (TMO) acquisition pushed Dionex (DNEX) to 118 from 98.
Life sciences-diagnostics companies also sell a lot of consumables, such as test tubes and microscope slides. Those use-and-replace add-ons have much higher margins than their host machines.
For every host machine companies sell, they tend to sell an equal dollar amount of consumables within five years, Cease says.
Mettler-Toledo (MTD) is up 55% from a year ago. After breaking out of a basing pattern to a new high Feb. 8, the stock ran up 11% and then pulled back to its 10-week line, where it's found support.
Earnings growth climbed back above 20% the past three quarters after stumbling the prior six.
This maker of scales is adept at organic growth through acquisition, Cease says.
Analysts expect Bruker's (BRKR) Q1 earnings to jump 50% on a 23% increase in sales. A member of the IBD 50, its stock is extended after recently jumping off its 10-week moving average line.
Firms in the electronics subset make test and measurement gear. The products are used to vet new gizmos used in telecom networks, data centers and chip applications, as well as routing and switching.
The Electronics Side
The electronics subset is more volatile. It had a bigger jump off the market bottom.
IPG Photonics (IPGP), a leading maker of fiber-optic lasers, has four quarters of triple-digit EPS growth. Those followed four stanzas of declines.
Bob Auer, manager of $232 million Auer Growth Fund , likes Newport (NEWP). Like IPG, it is a maker of lasers and related gear. Its products are used in everything from eye surgery to missile defense.
Auer is bullish on Newport through 2011. He likes the company's fast growth, increase in backlogs and guidance for sales to hit an all-time record.

Cease is slightly more bullish on the electronics segment. 5:15 p.m. Update: The major indexes scored tall gains Wednesday, as a handful of leading stocks staged breakouts.
The Nasdaq sparked up 4.6%, the S&P 500 3.5%, the NYSE composite 3.2% and the Dow 2.9%.
Mid- and small caps ran ahead of larger issues, with the S&P 400 posting a 5.3% advance and the S&P 600 jumping 5.5%.

Volume ran thin throughout the session, even in comparison to Tuesday's weak trading levels. Preliminary data showed NYSE trading slumped 24% while Nasdaq volume sagged 21%. Light trading is typical ahead of a holiday.

Advancing issues led decliners by better than 5-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 4-to-1 margin on the Nasdaq. Five of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD posted gains of better than 10% during the session. Three of those were steel or ore mining related.
Worth noting: NCI (NCIT), Cogent (COGT) and Strayer Education (STRA) all broke above buy points and held their session's gains. Volume in Strayer was barely above average, though.
Capella Education (CPLA) erased Tuesday's losses to end 12% higher for the week and closer to completion of a possible base.
Discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) recovered most of its sharp, early losses to end the week 18% higher, and 3% above a 40.58 buy point after Monday's breakout from a 10-week, cup-with-handle base.
No major economic reports are due out Friday. Stock markets are scheduled to close early, with trading on the Nasdaq and NYSE set to end at 1 p.m. EST.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close At Session Highs; Volume Ebbs
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market brushed aside more gloomy news on the economy as NYSE indexes posted their fourth-straight gain.
The NYSE composite rose 3.2%, the S&P 500 3.5%, the Dow 2.9%, according to preliminary totals. The Nasdaq rose 4.6%.
Major indexes closed at session highs.
But volume was lower, as is typical of a pre-holiday session.
Commodity-related industry groups such as steel makers and oil producers led the market.
3:15 p.m. Update: Leading Stocks Hold Gains As Indexes Climb
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes staked out higher ground in shy volume as trading swung into the final stretch.
The Nasdaq maintained its lead, up 3.3%. Known primarily for its technology stocks, the Nasdaq's mortgage and real estate names were leading.
The S&P 500 moved 2.5% higher. The NYSE composite and the Dow rose 2.2% and 1.8%, respectively.
Midcaps continued to outperform, driving the S&P 400 ahead 4.2%.
Volume remained lower. Even if the major indexes closed with sizeable gains, a follow-through could not happen unless volume finishes higher than Wednesday's level.
Mettler-Toledo (MTD), Capella Education (CPLA)and Astec Industries (ASTE) were among advancing stocks in strong volume.
Astec has reclaimed its 50-day moving average as it tries to recover from a steep slide.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Trim Some Gains, Still Higher
BY PATRICK CAIN
Indexes pared some gains in afternoon trading, but remained higher.
The Dow was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 1.2% and the Nasdaq 2.4%. The NYSE composite added 0.9%.
Volume was tracking lower, as it typically does in a preholiday session.

Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao (CBD), a Brazilian grocery store chain, rose 5%. The company reported after the market closed Tuesday that profit soared 138% to $39 million on increased sales and lower expenses. The stock has reclaimed its 50-day moving average.
Axsys Technologies (AXYS), a maker of camera systems for homeland security, rose 3%. The stock is nearing the high of a low handle, part of a double-bottom base.

Canadian telecom giant BCE (BCE) plummeted 35%. The company said the deal to take it private is unlikely to close after a preliminary review finding that the proposed $35 billion deal may not meet solvency requirements.
Making a comeback is Tiffany (TIF). The high-end jeweler was off 4% after being down 11% in pre-market action. The stumble came on a weak outlook. Shares remain deep in a correction.
1:15 p.m. Update: Telecoms, Midcaps Haul Indexes Higher
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Major indexes pressed higher in a day of soft trading ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.
The Nasdaq composite rode a 2.8% gain. The NYSE composite and the Dow each pulsed 1.1% higher. The S&P 500 ran 1.5% into the black.

Midcaps outperformed the general market, with the S&P 400 surging 3.4%. The Nasdaq's telecom index posted its strongest gain, up 4%. Baidu.com (BIDU) added 13% in solid volume, exerting a strong influence on the Nasdaq 100.
Volume recovered from its lows but was still down nearly 20% on both exchanges vs. Tuesday's soft trading levels.

Cogent (COGT) popped 4% in solid volume, breaking above a 12.48 buy point on a nine-week, cup-shaped base. The maker of automated fingerprint identification equipment was upgraded to overweight by JPMorgan on Nov. 19.

Mining and heavy construction equipment maker Astec Industries  (ASTE) punched 16% higher in big volume after Canaccord Adams initiated coverage with a buy rating. On Tuesday, the Tennessee-based company reported Q3 earnings growth of 39%, well above consensus views. Shares are climbing up from a yearlong correction.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Improve Near Halfway Point
BY VINCENT MAO
The major stock indexes improved near the halfway mark of the session as a few high-rated stocks broke out of bases.

The Nasdaq led the charge, gaining 2.1%. Bellwethers Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and Research In Motion (RIMM) boosted the tech-heavy index. The NYSE composite, Dow and S&P 500 climbed out of the red, rising 0.3%, 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively.
Volume continued to track sharply lower across the board. Advancers beat decliners by more than 2-to-1 on both major exchanges.
Thinly traded NCI  (NCIT) jumped 7% and cleared a 26.95 buy point from a handle. Volume was tracking at more than triple its average.
Education issues advanced after leader Strayer Education (STRA) cleared a slightly high handle.
New Oriental Education & Technology Group (EDU) rallied for the fourth straight session, up 8%. The stock continued to rebound from its lowest levels since March 2007.
Capella Education (CPLA) erased early losses and gained 8% in fast trade. The online school operator will be added to the small-cap S&P 600 after the close.
Apollo Group (APOL) also reversed earlier losses and climbed 5% to a nine-month high.
11:15 a.m. Update: Tech Rebound Stirs Mixed Action In Weak Trading
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Tech stocks appeared to rebound from Tuesday's losses, pulling the Nasdaq higher and lifting other major indexes off their early lows.
The Nasdaq composite steered to a 1.5% gain. The NYSE composite and the Dow held 0.5% below the waterline. The S&P 500 showed a 0.6% loss. Small caps ran higher, with the S&P 600 up 1%.
Health care and international stocks led the NYSE's downside. The Nasdaq's telecom and computer makers indexes showed its best gains.
Pre-holiday trading volume was predictably low, down about 30% on both exchanges vs. Tuesday's soft trading levels.

More economic news rolled in further confirming the difficult state of the economy. A fall in new orders drove the November Chicago Purchasing Managers Index of Midwest business activity to 33.8, down from October's 37.8. That was its biggest monthly drop since 1982 and well below expectations for a rise to 38.5.
The University of Michigan revised its consumer sentiment index down to 55.3 from 57.9, which had represented a mild gain from October's number.
Crude oil futures held in the $52 to $53 a barrel range. Commodities moved generally higher, although gold continued backing away from Monday's five-week high.

Swiss-based Mettler Toledo (MTD) gapped up and gained 4% after Standard & Poor's announced the maker of laboratory instruments would replace Border's Group (BGP) on the midcap S&P 400 at the close of trading Dec. 1.
Southwestern Energy (SWN)edged up with a 2% advance. The natural gas producer is back above 10-week support, attempting to build a workable base from a sloppy correction begun in July.

Deere (DE) gapped down to a 9% loss after reporting fiscal Q4 earnings below expectations and guiding '09 forecasts below consensus views. The world's largest farm equipment maker, Deere's stock has been correcting since April.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fight Back From Lower Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks battled back from some worse-than-expected economic data, turning mixed early Wednesday.
The Nasdaq was the lone gainer, up 0.1%. The NYSE composite fell 1.4%, the S&P 500 1.1% and the Dow 1%.
Volume was down over 30% on both exchanges.
New-home sales tumbled 5.3% in October to an annual rate of 433,000 units, below expectations.

In company news, Rio Tinto (RTP) gapped down and tumbled 14% to its lowest levels in more than four years. That extended Tuesday's 27% dive after BHP Billiton (BHP) withdrew its $68 billion takeover offer.
Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) dropped 3% after MKM Partners cut the discount retailer to neutral from buy. On Tuesday, Dollar Tree reported a 24% rise in Q3 profit and raised its full-year outlook.
Toyota Motor (TM) fell 5% after Fitch Ratings cut a couple of the automaker's ratings.

Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs slashed its outlook on overall auto sales through 2010. The broker trimmed 2008 sales estimate to 13.4 million from 13.8 million. Sales for 2009 are now seen at 11 million units, down from prior estimates of 13 million. 2010 sales are expected to hit 13 million, down from previous forecasts for 14 million.
Despite the outlook, Ford  (F) and General Motors (GM) each gained 6%.
Elsewhere, Strayer Education (STRA)rose a fraction. Earlier, the stock cleared a 235.60 buy point from a high handle.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Headed For Down Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a vastly weaker open Wednesday following disappointing economic reports.
Nasdaq futures dropped 15 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 15 points and Dow futures shed 139 points.
A barrage of economic reports hit Wall Street.
Orders for durable goods tumbled 6.2% in October, the largest decline in two years and much worse than estimates for a 2.5% drop. Excluding transportation, orders fell 4.4%.
Initial jobless claims fell by a larger-than-expected 14,000 to 529,000. Claims in the prior week were revised to 543,000 from 542,000.
Personal income rose 0.3% vs. an expected 0.1% rise. But consumer spending dropped 1%, or worse than views of a 0.7% fall. It was the weakest number since September 2001.
Meanwhile, the Chicago PMI for November will be out at 9:45 a.m. EST. The regional factory gauge is seen rising to 38.5 from 37.8 in October.
The revised University of Michigan Sentiment Index will be out at 10 a.m. EST. Also out at that time will be October new-home sales.
President-elect Barrack Obama is expected to announce former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker as head of a special economic advisory group.

In company news, Tiffany (TIF) stumbled 11% in the pre-market after it delivered a mixed Q3 report and gave a weak outlook. The luxury goods retailer reported earnings of 35 cents a share, up 21% from a year earlier and 10 cents above views. But sales edged down 1% to $618.2 million vs. views of $643.8 million. Tiffany pegged full-year profit in a range of $2.30 to $2.50 a share vs. analysts' estimates of $2.58.

J. Crew Group (JCG) late Tuesday reported a 29% drop in Q3 earnings but still topped views. On the downside, the trendy clothing retailer cut its full-year outlook to $1.11 to $1.16 a share vs. views of $1.36.
Overseas, European bourses were lower despite the EU's proposal of a $256 billion economic stimulus plan. London's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX each fell more than 2%.
China cut its ley interest rate by 1.08% to 5.58%  the most in 11 years  in an effort to boost it slowing economy. Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose nearly 4%.
Elsewhere, crude oil jumped $1.58 to $52.35 a barrel.

4:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Gives Up Gains; Market Ends Lower
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The stock market closed lower Wednesday after the Nasdaq surrendered its gains in the final minutes.

Stocks started higher on a surprising reading for the service sector. But the market faded amid uncertainty about the White House's new financial rescue plan.
Volume rose, adding to the session's weak tone.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Put Flaps Down, Drive Lower In Busy Trade
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
The Dow nose-dived to a 1.4% loss as Bank of America (BAC) tanked to new lows. Dow heavyweights Wal-Mart (WMT) and Procter & Gamble (PG) each gave up 3%, also weighing heavily on the index.
The NYSE composite and the S&P 500 fell 0.5% and 0.7% apiece. Most NYSE industry sectors had slipped into the red. The Healthcare Index led the retreat with a 1.3% loss. Energy held a 0.3% gain.
The Nasdaq composite hovered at the break-even mark, as Sun Microsystems (JAVA), Apple (AAPL) and Hewlett Packard (HPQ) hauled the exchange's computer makers index up 0.8%.
Trading volume continued apace on both exchanges, solidly above Tuesday's above-average action.

Crude oil futures turned from mild gains to mild losses to close at just below $41 a barrel. Gold eased from early, strong gains to settle $3.30 higher at $905.50 an ounce. Other commodities traded mixed as the dollar firmed against the euro but remained lower vs. the yen.

HMS Holdings (HMSY) rode 4% higher in strong trading. A cost efficiency and receivables manager for health care providers, the stock is grabbing 52-week highs as it climbs up from a long-term consolidation.
2:15 p.m. Update: Dow Goes Negative As Indexes Pull Back
BY PATRICK CAIN
The retreat continued, pushing the Dow into negative territory.
The Dow fell 0.6%, while the S&P 500 was up 0.1%, the Nasdaq 0.7%, the NYSE composite 0.3%.
Volume was up and accelerating from its lunchtime lows.
Materials and industrial industry groups such as steel producers, fertilizers and machinery were up the most on the day. Auto-related groups also rallied.

Ryder Systems (R), a provider of leased vehicles and logistics, dropped 13%. It was the biggest loser among S&P 500 stocks. The company reported a decline in earnings with $1.09 a share, but that beat views. Ryder estimated 2009 revenue at $5.4 billion, down from $6.2 billion in 2008.
Apollo Group (APOL) was off 3% but in light volume. The education firm remained within 5% of its previous high after testing its 10-week moving average.
On the upside, Shire (SHPGY) gained 3%. The maker of treatments for disorders of the central nervous systems ran up to its 40-week moving average.
Biotech Biogen (BIIB) was up 2% and back above its 200-day moving average for the first time since a 28% plunge Aug. 1. It's up 10% so far on the week.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Pull Back As Volume Eases
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
The Dow and the NYSE led a mild retreat from session highs as earnings news turned.

The Nasdaq composite still held a 1.5% gain, down from its earlier, 2.2% peak. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 remained up 0.9% and 0.8%, respectively. The Dow retracted to a 0.1% gain as Kraft Foods (KFT), Walt Disney (DIS) and Bank of America (BAC) continued to slump amid heavy selling.
The NYSE's Healthcare Index retreated 0.2%. Illumina (ILMN), Seagate Technology (STX) and Electronic Arts (ERTS) headed the Nasdaq's gains.
Volume eased off its early strength, but remained firmly higher on both exchanges. The margin between advancing and declining issues narrowed, holding well below the 2-to-1 level.
Crude futures remained relatively flat while most other commodities turned in solid gains. The dollar added to its gains against the euro and slipped further vs. the yen.
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index chalked up a 3.6% advance, riding the heels of NetLogic (NETL), which popped 17% in huge volume.
Shire Group (SHPGY) cracked open a 3% gain in heavy trade, putting the therapeutic drugmaker flush with resistance at its 200-day moving average.
Another therapeutic drugmaker, Biogen (BIIB) rallied 2% at nearly double its average pace. Shares are climbing the right side of a five- month cup.

On the downside, vehicle leasing operator Ryder (R) crumbled 12% after reporting an 85% rockslide in its Q4 earnings on an 18% drop in sales. The company said declines in its commercial rental operations had now expanded into its fleet management and third-party truck supply segments.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retreat Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back after hitting new session highs midday Wednesday.

The Nasdaq was up 1.8%, down from an intraday peak of 2.2%. But the index remains above its 50-day moving average after reclaiming it earlier. Gains in Google (GOOG), Apple (AAPL) and Electronic Arts (ERTS) boosted the index.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 1.1% each. Meanwhile, the Dow lagged with a 0.4% gain. Losses in Kraft Foods (KFT) and Walt Disney  (DIS) weighed on the blue-chip index.
Volume was again tracking sharply higher on both exchanges.

Cephalon (CEPH) rose 3% in brisk trade, clearing a 80.48 buy point from a handle. The stock has already traded nearly 100% of its average daily volume. Cephalon reports earnings Feb. 12. Analysts see the drugmaker's profit rising 64% to $1.36 a share.

Edwards Lifesciences (EW) reversed early losses and climbed 4%. Late Tuesday, the medical device maker beat views with a 39% jump in Q4 earnings. That marked the fourth straight quarter of accelerating growth. But sales grew 6%, below views.
On the downside, Dollar Tree (DLTR) fell 4% on a downgrade. Due to valuation, JPMorgan cut the discount retailer to neutral from overweight.
JPMorgan also cut food processor Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) to neutral from overweight. Shares dropped 6%.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Power Up On Earnings, January ISM Jump
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Big investors were clearly in the building as volume jumped well beyond Tuesday's above-average levels.

The Nasdaq composite pointed the way higher, up 2% and near the top of the morning's trading range. The NYSE composite rose 1.4%. The S&P 500 edged a bit off its high, up 1.1%. The Dow lagged with a 0.6% gain, hamstrung by Kraft Foods (KFT), Walt Disney (DIS), General Motors (GM) and Bank of America (BAC).
Volume jumped decisively on both exchanges, up 13% on the Nasdaq and 20% on the NYSE.
Advancing issues led decliners by broader than 2-to-1 on both exchanges.

The Institute of Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index reading of 42.9 for January was up from 40.1 in December and well above consensus views for 39. The measure showed that the economy continued to contract in January, but at a slower rate.

The March crude oil contract hovered slightly higher, just above $41 a barrel. Gold bounded ahead more than $14 to $907 an ounce. Commodities ran broadly higher as the dollar slipped vs. the euro and gained ground against the yen.
In stocks, Terra Nitrogen (TNH) pulled 4% higher in strong trading. That broke the Iowa-based fertilizer maker above the left side high of a four month, cup-shaped base.
E-travel Web site Priceline (PCLN) grabbed a 3% gain in nearly double its average trade. Shares are five weeks into a possible base after suffering through an eight-month correction.

On the downside, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) gapped down to give up 3% in huge trading. The wholesale coffee distributor broke out of a four month cup-with-handle base Tuesday with a 9% gain.

Overseas, markets across Asia posted solid gains, with key indexes in Shanghai, Hong Kong and Tokyo all gaining well over 2%. Markets in Europe and the U.K. ran even stronger, with Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris both climbing 3.3%. The FTSE 100 in London bulked up 1.8%.

BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks climbed in early trading Wednesday after bobbing and weaving at the open. They strengthened after better-than-expected economic data

Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges, especially on the NYSE.
In economic news, the ISM services index unexpectedly rose to a reading of 42.9, beating views of 39.

Illumina (ILMN) gapped up and surged 13% after it smashed Q4 views and gave a bullish outlook. It guided Q1 and full-year results above analysts' estimates.
NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) gapped up and climbed 10% following its better-than-expected results late Tuesday. The chipmaker's Q4 earnings fell 9% to 30 cents a share, beating views by 7 cents.

Clorox  (CLX) rose 5% after it beat views. Before the open, the bleach maker delivered fiscal Q2 profit of 62 cents a share, down from 69 cents the prior year but a nickel above views. The company affirmed its full-year earnings outlook but trimmed its sales forecast. It also announced plans to cut 170 jobs.

On the downside, Universal Technical Institute (UTI) gapped down and tumbled 28% after reporting a bigger-than-expected downturn in earnings late Tuesday. Universal trains automotive and marine technicians. That dragged down fellow school operators DeVry (DV), ITT Educational Services (ESI) and Strayer Education (STRA).
Rambus (RMBS) gapped down and dived 13% after a judge postponed a patent infringement case filed by the company against Micron Technology (MU).

BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a mixed open Wednesday following a weaker-than-expected ADP employment report and lackluster earnings.
Nasdaq futures slipped a fraction of a point vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rose 3 points and Dow futures shed 15 points.
The ADP employment index said the private sector lost 522,000 jobs in January, worse than forecasts for a loss of 515,000 jobs.

At 10 a.m. EST, the ISM services index for January will be released. Forecasts call for a drop to 39 from 40.1 in December.

In corporate news, Kraft Foods (KFT) tumbled 10% in the pre-open after missing views and lowering its outlook. Kraft lowered its full-year 2009 earnings guidance to $1.88 a share, down from $2 previously. Views are for $2.02 a share.

Meanwhile, Walt Disney (DIS) slumped 7% in the pre-open following its weaker-than-expected results late Tuesday. The media giant posted fiscal Q1 earnings of 41 cents a share, excluding items, well below views of 52 cents.

Industry peer Time Warner (TWX) swung to a Q4 loss of $16.03 billion, or $4.47 a share, hurt by a $24.2 billion write-down. Excluding items, earnings fell to 23 cents a share from 29 cents a year earlier, missing views by 3 cents. Sales fell 3% to $12.31 billion, also below views. Time Warner expects flat full-year earnings. Shares fell 3% in the pre-market.

Costco (COST) shed 7% in the pre-open after reporting a 2% decline in January same-store sales. The discount grocer also warned that fiscal Q2 profit will be "substantially below" analysts' forecast of 70 cents a share. Costco will stop giving earnings outlooks for the rest of the year.
Panasonic (PC) expects an annual loss of $4.2 billion and will slash up to 15,000 jobs and close 27 plants.

Elsewhere, networking giant Cisco Systems (CSCO) reports earnings after the close. Medical sectors issues led the gains through most of the day, overpowering some weak economic news and a credit downgrade on General Electric (GE).

4:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Erases Loss For 2009
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
Friday's stock surge put the Nasdaq up for the year.
The composite soared 2.9%, the NYSE composite 2.8%, the S&P 500 and Dow 2.7% each.
Volume fell from Thursday's strong levels, a bit of damper in an otherwise strong day. Advancing stocks led decliners by 5-to-1 on the NYSE and by 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Financial, consumer-related and metals groups led the market.
3:15 p.m. Update: Banks, Homebuilders & Transports Prop Up Gains
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes backed off their highs but carried most of the session's broad, soft advance into the final hour of trading.
The NYSE and Nasdaq composites each held 2.7% gains. The Dow maintained a 2.6% advance and the S&P 500 kept to a 2.4% rise.
The Dow Transports socked away a 5.4% win, as FedEx (FDX) added 6%, UPS (UPS) edged 3% higher and Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings (AAWW) packed on a big volume, 26% growth spurt.
Residential builders gapped up as a group and gained nearly 9%. D.R. Horton (DHI) jumped 18%. Centex (CTX) swung 17% higher.
Volume flatlined through most of the session safely below Thursday's above-average activity.

Aeropostale (ARO) ladled up a 4% gain in above-average trading. The hipster, mall-crowd clothier on Thursday reported its January same-store sales rose 11%. Shares received an upgrade to strong buy from Standard & Poor's on Friday. The stock has climbed in seven of the past eight weeks as it scales up from a five-month consolidation.
Priceline (PCLN) stepped 2% higher, pushing its five-day run to an 11% gain so far, for the week. The online travel site is in the fifth week of a possible cup base.
2:15 p.m. Update: After breather, Stocks Resume Run-Up
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks continued their climb, although volume remained lower compared with the levels at this time yesterday.
The Dow and S&P 500 were up 2.8%, while the Nasdaq and NYSE composite rose 3%. Thursday was the highest volume in the Nasdaq since November.
Advancing stocks led decliners by 11-to-2 on the NYSE and by nearly 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Aaron Rents (RNT), a home furnishings rental company, jumped 8%. The stock ran up to its 40-week moving average where the move has stalled.
Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM), the Chilean producer of specialty fertilizers, gained 4%. The stock is trading at its 200-day moving average for the first time since Sept. 25.
American peer Terra Nitrogen (TNH) was off. The Iowa firm fell 4%. This week the stock staged an ugly reversal, giving up a 12% gain. It's now negative on the week in huge volume.

Cardiovascular product maker Thoratec (THOR) dropped 5%. The stock is down 11% on the week, plunging itself below the 10-week moving average. The company reported Q4 earnings that beat on sales but missed on earnings. Revenue was boosted by sales of HeartMate II.
Diet company Weight Watchers (WTW) slipped 4% after Barclays Capital downgraded it to underweight from equal weight. That sent it to an all-time low.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hold High Ground as Volume Fades
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Advancing issues held sway, topping decliners by 5-to-1 on the NYSE and better then 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq as indexes held near their highs in afternoon trading.
The Nasdaq composite caught up to the Dow, both packing 2.3% gains. The NYSE composite ran 2.2% higher and the S&P 500 rode up 2.1%.

Banks packed the top ranks of the Dow's leaders, with Bank of America (BAC) running at the head of the pack. Joy Global (JOYG), Logitech (LOGI) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) headed the Nasdaq 100's upside.
Volume caved to near its lowest marks of the day, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 10% lower on the NYSE.
March futures for crude oil held below $40 a barrel. Most commodities traded lower, while copper held its 5% gain. The dollar continued to slide vs. the euro and gain against the yen.
Visa (V) gained 2% in strong trading. The payment processor advanced in the prior two sessions and is up 12% for the week.

Ross Stores (ROST) rode a 5% advance. The discount retail chain reported January same-store sales fell 2%, better than expectations for a 2.9% drop. The company boosted EPS guidance for the October-to-January period to between 75 cents and 76 cents vs. prior guidance of 73 cents to 75 cents. Ross also increased its dividend by 16% to 11 cents.

On the downside, scale maker Mettler-Toledo (MTD) continued to take a pounding, off 13% in torrential volume. The company received a handful of analyst downgrades after reporting Q4 results late Thursday. The gap-down loss left shares at their lowest mark since August '06.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Take Breather After Morning Run
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks eased near the halfway point of Friday's session. They have been running higher since the open.
The Dow jumped 2.3% with all 30 components in positive territory. The Nasdaq climbed 2.1%, S&P 500 2% and NYSE composite 1.9%.
Volume, however, was now tracking lower across the board.
Neutral Tandem (TNDM) rallied 5% in fast trade, extending Thursday's 11% gain. The company's products and services let competing carrier exchange network traffic.

American Italian Pasta (AIPC) rose 3% to near four-year high. In December, the company delivered a 260% pop in Q4 earnings. Analysts see another triple-digit gain this quarter. The stock emerged from a rebound off its 10-week moving average.

On the downside, SRA International (SRX) gapped down and tumbled 22% in huge volume. Late Thursday, the IT services firm delivered fiscal Q2 results below expectations and cut its full-year outlook. This morning BB&T Capital Markets cut the stock to hold from buy.

Oneok Partners (OKS) dropped 7% and sliced its 50-day moving average. After Thursday's close, the natural gas processing firm guided full-year 2008 earnings at the lower half of its prior outlook and full-year 2009 earnings below views. Earlier this morning, Tudor Pickering cut the stock to hold from accumulate.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Plow Past Soft Jobs Data To Session Highs
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Financials were the clear leaders as markets moved forward with broad gains.
The Dow shed the laggard role it had played so far this week, gaining 1.9%. Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C) headed the leaders list.
The NYSE composite pulled 1.7% higher. The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 added 1.6%, with Nasdaq 100 issues Research In Motion (RIMM) and Amazon.com (AMZN) posting strong gains.
Trading volume showed mixed, up a notch on the NYSE and firmly lower on the Nasdaq.

March crude futures slipped $1.45 to below $40 a barrel. London's Brent crude benchmark backed down $1 to just above $45. Other commodities traded up and down, with copper jumping 5% higher. The dollar fell vs. the euro but gained against the yen.

Syngenta (SYT) tacked on a heavy-volume, 3% gain after reporting its full fiscal '08 results. The Switzerland-based agricultural products maker said revenue climbed 21% to $11.6 billion. EPS soared 42% to $16.26. Shares are four weeks into a possible cup base.
Gymboree (GYMB) bounced 4% in better than double its average trading.

Aaron Rents (RNT) jumped 7%, notching a 13% gain so far for the week. That bounce pulled the rent-to-own furniture and appliance chain back from last week's 15% sell-off. But shares were still below key levels of support.

On the downside, Netflix (NFLX) slipped 5% in heavy trading. A Needham & Co. analyst downgraded the stock to underperform, citing concerns that shares reflected too high a value for the company's streaming online movie offering. Shares remained in a tight range to last Friday's close.
Markets across Asia socked away solid gains. Benchmark indexes in Shanghai and Hong Kong sailed well over 3%. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo popped 1.6%.
Europe and the U.K. also ran higher, with the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX clearing better-than 2% gains. London's FTSE 100 showed 2.3% higher in late trading.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Brush Off Dismal Payroll Report
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks shot out of the gate Friday, shaking off a round of dismal employment data.
The Dow, Nasdaq, and NYSE composite each rallied 1.5%, while the S&P 500 rose 1.4%.
Volume was mixed, with NYSE tracking sharply higher and Nasdaq slightly lower.
Financials were among the biggest winners on prospects of more government help and fewer fears of nationalization.

Bank of America  (BAC) gapped up and surged 15%. It continued to bounce back after touching a 24-year low Thursday. Chief Executive Ken Lewis recently bought nearly $1 million in BofA stock, adding to his position.
Citigroup (C) climbed 11% and Wells Fargo (WFC) rallied 9%.
Meanwhile, a couple of IBD 100 firms scored nice gains.

CNA Surety (SUR) gapped up and rose 8% on a strong fourth-quarter financial report. Before the open, the company delivered Q4 earnings of 66 cents a share, up 27% from a year earlier and 15 cents above estimates. Sales grew 5%, also above views.

Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) climbed 5% in fast trade. The stock might be forming a deep handle. Its relative strength line is already at a new high ahead of price, indicating market outperformance.

On the downside, Biogen Idec (BIIB) fell 3% as disappointing sales of its Tysabri MS drug offset better-than-expected Q4 earnings. Sales of Tysabri, co-marketed with Elan (ELN), came in at $218 million, or shy of analysts' estimates of $250 million. Elan shares slid 4%.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Set For Higher Start, Despite Grim Jobs Data
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a slightly higher open Friday despite worse-than-expected economic data.
Nasdaq futures rose a fraction of a point vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures gained nearly 3 points and Dow futures climbed 22 points.
On the economic front, the Labor Department said employers slashed 598,000 jobs in January. That's the highest number since December 1974 and worse than forecasts for a loss of 540,000 jobs.

December payrolls were revised to minus 577,000 jobs from minus 524,000 previously. November job losses also were revised higher. The economy has now lost 3.57 million jobs since the start of the recession in December 2007.
The unemployment rate ticked up to 7.6% from 7.2% in December. Economists expected 7.5%.
The Senate is expected to vote on the $900 billion-plus stimulus bill later today. Meanwhile, details about possible help for banks are expected on Monday.

In corporate news, Toyota  (TM) fell 3% in the pre-market after posting a fiscal Q3 loss of $1.81 billion. The automaker also warned of its first annual loss since 1950. Just before the earnings release, Moody's Investor Services cut Toyota's top credit rating on fears about profitability.
Group mates Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) were indicated lower.

Hartford Financial Services Group (HIG) late Thursday reported a Q4 loss of 72 cents a share vs. views for a profit of $1.30 a share. Chief Executive Ramani Ayer called 2008 "the most challenging year" in the company's nearly 200-year history. Hartford also slashed its dividend to a nickel a share from 32 cents previously. Shares tumbled 19% in the pre-market

Media giant News Corp. (NWS) slipped 2% in the pre-open following Thursday night's disappointing quarterly results. Hurt by huge asset write-downs, the company's Q2 profit plunged 56% from the prior year to 12 cents a share, or 7 cents below views. Sales fell 3%, also below views.

In evaluating the Zacks Industry Ranks, you want to see two things: a good overall score (low, meaning more Zacks #1 and #2 Ranked stocks than #4 or #5 Ranked stocks) and some improvement the relative position from the prior week. It is also helpful to understand exactly what the Zacks Industry Rank is.

The Zacks Industry Rank is the un-weighted average of the individual Zacks ranks of the firms in that industry. It does not matter if the stock is the 800 lb gorilla that dominates the industry or some very small niche player in the industry -- they have the same influence on the industry rank.

Also, that means that the bigger the industry in terms of number of firms, the less influence any given company has on the industry rank. It also implies that small industries, with just two or three firms, should be the ones found at either the top or the bottom of the list. After all, if there are only two firms in the industry, it is relatively easy to get a Zacks rank of 2.00 (i.e. one with a Zacks Rank of #1 and the other with a #3). Right now, that industry rank would be tied for 6th place among the 255 industries tracked.

The same obviously goes for the bottom of the list as well. If there are 50 firms in the industry, and it ends up at one of the extremes, that means there has to be something pretty significant going on. Thus, I do not always focus on the very highest rated industries, but on the highest rated ones in which there are a large number of firms.

Key Points - Update:
Demand for industrial products remains good, despite the sluggish economy
Several industrial product companies have customers in sectors not significantly hurt by the credit crunch
Second-quarter results for industrial product companies aided by stronger economic growth abroad and the weaker dollar
Despite the sluggish economy, many industrial product companies are continuing to enjoy growth. There are two primary reasons for this:
The first is that many of these companies have exposure to sectors that have not been significantly hurt by the U.S. economic slowdown, such as energy, food, scientific research and utility.

The second is international sales. Most countries in Europe and Asia are experiencing stronger growth than the U.S. Furthermore, the weak dollar makes U.S. products more price competitive to overseas customers. And, as sales conducted overseas are translated back into dollars, a gain is realized. This is because each euro is worth about $1.55 in U.S. dollars.

These two factors have allowed several industrial product companies to both report strong second-quarter reports and raise their full-year guidance, including Cooper Industries (CBE), Mettler-Toledo (MTD  -  Free Report) and Woodward Governor (WGOV).
An Electric Quarter For Cooper Industries

Cooper Industries, which makes electrical and circuit protection products as well as hand tools, earned 97 cents per share in the second quarter, on an adjusted basis, versus 78 cents a year prior. Brokerage analysts had expected profits to total 92 cents.
Revenues rose 18% to $1.72 billion, reflecting organic growth, the positive impact of acquisitions and the weak dollar.
The company's Electrical Products segment was particularly strong, with sales increasing 19%. Strong demand from the industrial, utility and energy markets all played favorable roles.

Citing the positive business momentum, CBE raised its full-year guidance to between $3.61 and $3.71 per share. Nearly all of the 9 covering brokerage analysts raised their forecasts in response, sending the consensus earnings estimate five cents higher to $3.62 per share.
Mettler-Toledo Profits Measure Up

Mettler-Toledo credited its broad customer base for propelling revenues 20%. The company, which makes weighing and laboratory analytical instruments, saw sales reach $515.6 million, versus $430.5 million a year prior. Per share earnings totaled $1.38 per share, 29% above last year's level and 10 cents better than the consensus earnings estimate.
MTD generated double-digit growth in its laboratory, industrial and retail segments. A weak dollar helped boost demand internationally and contributed to the overall growth.

The company increased its full-year EPS guidance by 10 cents to a range of $5.53 and $5.63 per share. Positive revisions from 6 of the 7 covering brokerage analysts caused the consensus earnings estimate to rise 10 cents to $5.63 per share.
Woodward Governor Blows Past Expectations

Woodward Governor, which makes power systems, saw fiscal third-quarter sales rise 23% to $329.8 million. WGOV's Electrical Power Systems unit was a key drive, with growth coming from the power generation and wind turbine inverter markets. The company also enjoyed double-digit growth in its larger turbine and engine systems units.
The sales growth translated into second-quarter profits of 47 cents per share, a sharp increase over year-prior results of 34 cents. Brokerage analysts had forecast 44 cents.
Based on the results, CEO Thomas Gendron raised his full-year EPS guidance to $1.75 per share, seven higher than the consensus estimate.

Not only did nearly all of the covering brokerage analysts raise their profit projections for fiscal 2008 in response, they also raised their projections for fiscal 2009. This weeks screen isnt so much a screen, but rather a look at how using a market sentiment item can help find new stock picks.
The item is called the short ratio.

The short ratio is the number of shares sold short (short interest or bets that the stock will go lower in price) divided by the average daily volume. This is sometimes referred to as the "days to cover" ratio because it tells approximately how many days it will take short-sellers to cover their positions if good news sends the price higher.
The higher the ratio, the longer it would take to buy back the sold (borrowed) shares. And in theory, the more short positions there are to cover, the stronger the short covering rally would be.

Many people who use this indicator like to look for the number of days to cover to be higher than 8-10 days. Its generally believed that a short ratio of that size could prove difficult to cover and therefore trigger a strong rally on any hint of an upswing. (My personal preference is to take that into consideration, but also compare it to the industrys average ratio and the stocks own historical ratio.)
And while I wouldnt recommend using just the short ratio, I do think it can be a great tool for helping define great opportunities.
For example, sometimes when Im looking for stocks that have been in a lengthy consolidation, Ill look for those stocks with high short ratios.
Why?
Because consolidation ranges are basically areas of market indecision.

Bets are being made by both bullish and bearish investors. So finding stocks that are going back and forth near their price highs with a growing short ratio shows that ever-increasing bets are being made on prices going lower.

However, if the stock breaks out to the upside, properly positioned bulls will more than likely add to their winnings; undecided traders will now be convinced to get long; and shorts will have to scramble to cover their bearish bets. This can be an explosive situation.
This can be used quite effectively for bottom fishing too.
When a stock is getting battered and pundits are wrangling over whether its the bottom or not, you should pay close attention to the short ratio.
Of course, there has to be a reason for a stock to move higher. So seeing an improving fundamental outlook is important.
But when lopsided market sentiment seems to be at its worst (reflected in investors buying and selling) the short ratio can be just the thing to uncover extremes.

For beaten down stocks, you can search for companies near their 52 week lows with increasing short ratios. Or better yet, look for short ratios above their average values or even ones that are at (or near) their historical highs.

For stocks moving higher, try looking for historically high short ratios for stocks up 20% or more (new uptrend) or that have just rallied past an important moving average like the 50 or 200-day average. (Funds will often pile in at those points. So a large short ratio could propel the market significantly higher as huge buyers bid the market up while panicky shorts chase it even higher just to get out.)

A screen Im currently running, however, is not a bottom picking screen. In fact, its looking for stocks in solid uptrends. The parameters to this weeks screen are:  Up 20% or greater over the last 12 weeks.  Trading within 10% of their 52 week high.  With upward earnings estimate revisions for the current quarter over the last 4 weeks.  All of this is added to companies trading over $5.  And that have an average daily trading volume of at least 50,000 shares or more.
